user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl:
```c
static void OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl(fd_set *OS_set, OS_FdSet *OSAL_set)
{
    size_t       offset;
    size_t       bit;
    osal_index_t id;
    uint8        objids;
    int          osfd;

    for (offset = 0; offset < sizeof(OSAL_set->object_ids); ++offset)
    {
        objids = OSAL_set->object_ids[offset];
        bit    = 0;
        while (objids != 0)
        {
            id = OSAL_INDEX_C((offset * 8) + bit);
            if ((objids & 0x01) != 0 && id < OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES)
            {
                osfd = OS_impl_filehandle_table[id].fd;
                if (osfd < 0 || !FD_ISSET(osfd, OS_set))
                {
                    OSAL_set->object_ids[offset] &= ~(1 << bit);
                }
            }
            ++bit;
            objids >>= 1;
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl:
typedef struct
{
    uint8 object_ids[(OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES + 7) / 8];
} OS_FdSet
...
typedef uint32 osal_index_t
...
typedef uint8_t   uint8
...
#define OSAL_INDEX_C(X) ((osal_index_t)(X))
...
#define OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES 50
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler-specific language extensions are used in the provided code. The function and related symbols only use standard C constructs and user-defined macros/typedefs: local variables declared at function start, standard types (size_t, typedefs for integer types), ordinary casts via the OSAL_INDEX_C macro, array indexing, bitwise operations, and use of the POSIX fd_set/FD_ISSET macro (a standard API macro, not a compiler extension). There are no occurrences of known compiler-extension tokens or constructs such as __attribute__, __asm__, __declspec, __builtin_*, typeof (GCC), statement-expressions ({ ... }) GCC extension, inline assembly, pragmas specific to compilers, or other documented compiler-specific extensions. Therefore there are no fragments that require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
